speaker: sun
text: Can you believe that {{Child.name}} is already 4 years old? {{Child.pronoun.He}} loves playing outdoors, especially at the local park. Since the weather is so nice out today, your family heads over there for a picnic. What have you packed for dessert?

You, {{Child.name}}, and {{Child.pronoun.his}} grandpa are playing by the swings, and the air is filled with laughter. "Grandpa?" {{Child.name}} stops playing for a minute. "What was it like when you were a little boy?"

speaker: grandfather
text: Those were the days! My friends and I played outside all day, and there was barely any supervision. We even had a secret treehouse! But I’ll never forget the day when....

speaker: grandfather
text: Well... I’ll never forget the day my best friend didn’t show up to play. He had measles, which caused him to catch pneumonia, and he was in the hospital for nearly two weeks. I was so scared.

choices.text: Measles is nothing to be scared of...
It’s a good thing measles is rare these days

speaker: grandfather
text: As serious as a heart attack! Back in my day, lots of kids got sick with measles because there was no vaccine. That’s why I made sure to vaccinate you and your brother when you were babies.
moreInfo: About 1 out of every 20 children with measles gets pneumonia, and about 1 child in every 1,000 who get measles will die.

choices.text: I'll keep {{Child.name}} up to date with immunizations
We don't need the vaccine anymore, right?

speaker: grandfather
text: You’ve read the news, right? It may not be as common as the flu, but many children catch measles every year because they haven’t been immunized. It’s very contagious and spreads quickly!
moreInfo: Outbreaks continue every year in the U.S. because unvaccinated people bring it home from travel in other countries and spread it to others in their community. If one person is infected, 9 out of every 10 unvaccinated children who come in contact with that person will catch it.

choices.text: Maybe I should have a chat with {{Child.name}}'s doctor
But there could be risks to vaccinating!
Enough with the sad talk. Let's just eat now.

speaker: grandfather
text: Good idea! And enough about that for now - let's eat!

speaker: grandfather
text: Don’t take my word for it, you really should ask your pediatrician! You follow their advice for healthy diets and exercise. I'm sure they'd be happy to tell you all about measles too.
moreInfo: The measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is very safe. Possible side effects may include fever, mild rash, or swelling of glands in the cheeks or neck

choices.text: I might ask my friends first
OK, I get it. Can we please just eat?

speaker: grandfather
text: Alright, fine. Just go talk to a pediatrician. We all want to keep {{Child.name}} safe right?

You head home after a long day in the park. On the radio, you hear a news report that the rate of unvaccinated children has quadrupled in the past four years, and that measles outbreaks are occurring more frequently in the US. You’re nervous and want to protect your child’s health. Anxiety builds as you wonder if other kids in your neighborhood are vaccinated.

After a fun day at the park, you all head home. On the radio, you hear a news report saying that the rate of unvaccinated children has quadrupled in the past four years, and that measles outbreaks are occurring more frequently in the US. You're glad that you're planning to see your pediatrician and ensure that {{Child.name}} stays healthy.
